Theme 2 focuses on macroeconomic concepts.
Students are introduced to aggregate demand

617.text:
and supply and use the AD-AS model to analyse
changes in real output and the price level.

625.text:
They also examine demand-side and supply-side
policies and how direct controls are used

633.text:
as a means of improving an economy performance.
Students also look at the underlying assumptions

640.text:
of these policies and their likely impact
and effectiveness, as well as consider policy

647.text:
responses in an historical context.
Students will need to have knowledge of the

654.text:
UK economy in the last 10 years and they will
draw on local and national contexts as appropriate.

of economic history to inform debates, national

This topic introduces some important concepts:
the circular flow of income model and the

793.text:
multiplier.
Students need to understand these ideas in

799.text:
and of themselves, but also their impact on
other topics covered; for example, the significance

806.text:

use of AD/AS diagrams to show how events in

814.text:

822.text:

860.text:
in words what happens when an injection or
leakage changes and they need to understand

867.text:
that if the tendency to leak increases then
the multiplier falls.

875.text:
This topic brings together several different
aspects of economic growth.

884.text:
Students are asked to consider the difference
between actual and potential growth, the possible

889.text:
causes of growth, and its positive and negative
consequences. Periods of growth are placed

896.text:
in context by looking at the trade cycle model,
and in particular the likely characteristics

903.text:
of periods of high growth (booms) and periods
of negative growth (recessions). The concept

912.text:
of the output gap is also introduced and linked
to ideas of recession and boom. Output gaps

920.text:
should be understood both verbally and diagrammatically
Causes and constraints of growth are a useful

928.text:
basis for teaching Theme 4. Causes of growth
include investment, migration and exports.

938.text:
Constraints include instability of government,
inadequate skills of workforce and low productivity.

945.text:
Costs of growth include possible negative
consequences for income distribution, the

952.text:
Balance of Payments and the environment. Students
should also consider the opportunity cost

958.text:
of growth. Benefits of growth include possible
positive consequences for: living standards,

966.text:
tax revenues and profits. Students could evaluate
the link between growth and living standards.
